title: Kevin Glazer makes move to sell Manchester United shares amid revenue dip
text:
(Picture: Rex Features)

Kevin Glazer has made a move that makes selling his 13 per cent stake in Manchester United possible, with financial experts believing a sale is the only logical reason for his actions.

One of the six Glazer brothers who own shares in the club, Kevin is the first to look to sell his stake, a move instigated by him converting his B class shares into A class stock.

The Sun reports that he can only have done this in order to sell, as A class stocks are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, while B class cannot be – a move confirmed in documents filed at the USA’s Securities and Exchange Commission.

Kevin’s A class shares amount to 20,2899,366 in the Kevin Glazer Irrevocable Exempt Family Trust and another 3,765,392 through KEGT Holdings, with the total value around £320m.

It is potentially destabilising news after the club announced they are set to suffer a fall in revenue for the first time in 10 years, and that shirt sponsor Chevrolet will not be extending their deal.

However, while the other Glazer siblings have not made their intentions clear, they will actually gain more control of the club as a result of Kevin’s move.

Class B shares are worth 10 votes, while A class shares are worth just one, meaning the rest of the Glazer clan have more influence as Kevin’s declines.

The American siblings holds a combined 90% stake in the club after their father Malcolm died five years ago.

Which party would purchase Kevin’s shares is as yet unknown, although the Saudi Arabian government expressed an interest in buying out the family earlier this year.

The Glazers told the Saudis, at the time, that the club was not for sale, but they may return and bid for Kevin’s shares.
